text:
So... whats the status on building binaries out of Julia programs?
I've seen PackageCompiler, but the binaries are "big in size". 1.7 is rumored to have better static compilation.... Can we get complete AOT compilation in Julia, in the future？

elements.text:
So... whats the status on building binaries out of Julia programs?
I've seen PackageCompiler, but the binaries are "big in size". 1.7 is rumored to have better static compilation.... Can we get complete AOT compilation in Julia, in the future？

text:
> "big in size".
An argument is that if your application is supposed to be big (> GB), then the constant overhead (~100MB) of Julia's dynamic facilities is negligible.

elements.text: "big in size".
An argument is that if your application is supposed to be big (> GB), then the constant overhead (~100MB) of Julia's dynamic facilities is negligible.

text: To me, it seems like we could probably get smaller sysimage-like compiles if we were able to more agressively delete most of base and the stdlib. Has anyone looked into this?

elements.text: To me, it seems like we could probably get smaller sysimage-like compiles if we were able to more agressively delete most of base and the stdlib. Has anyone looked into this?

text: People have looked into it, it's an approach called 'tree shaking'. My understanding is that to do it right, you'd need basically just as much information as you'd need for the GPUCompiler style compilation, so it's not clear why one would take that approach instead.

elements.text: People have looked into it, it's an approach called 'tree shaking'. My understanding is that to do it right, you'd need basically just as much information as you'd need for the GPUCompiler style compilation, so it's not clear why one would take that approach instead.

text: the advantage would be that you might be able to allow for more dynamism. For example, if you know that all methods of a function don't touch something, it's OK to remove it even if there is dynamic dispatch on that function

elements.text: the advantage would be that you might be able to allow for more dynamism. For example, if you know that all methods of a function don't touch something, it's OK to remove it even if there is dynamic dispatch on that function

text: We could have dynamic dispatch with the GPUCompiler approach as well though

elements.text: We could have dynamic dispatch with the GPUCompiler approach as well though

text: It's discussed in Julian's document above

elements.text: It's discussed in Julian's document above
